[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-logger/src/macros.rs] [Macro: schema] [Display format exploit] In the %$val display format variants (lines 181-192, 223-234), can malicious Display trait implementations execute arbitrary code, leak sensitive memory, or cause panics when logs are generated during consensus round processing? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-logger/src/macros.rs] [Macro: schema] [Schema injection] Can the lone schema case (lines 237-247) be exploited to inject pre-constructed malicious schemas that bypass validation, allowing attackers to forge audit logs or manipulate security monitoring systems? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-logger/src/macros.rs] [Macro: schema] [Array construction] In the base case (line 133), does the array construction &[ $($val),* ] properly handle large numbers of values, or can attackers cause stack overflow by providing thousands of key-value pairs in a single log statement? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-logger/src/macros.rs] [Macro: schema] [Format template bypass] Can attackers exploit the format args handling (lines 141-150) to inject format templates that are processed but whose structured data is lost, allowing them to hide key-value pairs from security monitoring? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-logger/src/macros.rs] [Macro: fmt_args] [Format string injection] Does the ::std::format_args!($template, $($args)*) call on line 269 properly validate that $template is a string literal, or can attackers inject runtime-computed format strings containing %n or other dangerous format specifiers? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-logger/src/macros.rs] [Macro: fmt_args] [Argument mismatch] Can mismatches between format placeholders in $template and provided $args cause undefined behavior, buffer overruns, or information leakage when consensus round data is logged? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-logger/src/macros.rs] [Macro: fmt_args] [Option confusion] Since fmt_args returns None (line 264) when no format string is present and Some(...) otherwise (lines 269, 272), can this dual-return type cause validators to mishandle log formatting and accidentally expose unformatted sensitive data? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-logger/src/macros.rs] [Macro: fmt_args] [Key-value stripping] Do the identifier and literal key handling cases (lines 276-301, 304-329) correctly strip key-value pairs from format arguments, or can malicious log calls cause structured data to leak into the format string and expose consensus secrets? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-logger/src/macros.rs] [Integration] [Log injection via transactions] Can malicious transaction payloads craft inputs that, when logged via these macros, inject fake log entries that appear to come from validator consensus code, deceiving audit systems and security monitoring? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-logger/src/macros.rs] [Integration] [Disk exhaustion] If validators log transaction data or block proposals using these macros without size limits, can attackers submit massive transactions or blocks that fill validator disk space, preventing consensus operation and causing loss of liveness? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-logger/src/macros.rs] [Integration] [Log correlation attack] Can attackers analyze patterns in logged module_path!() (line 59) and file/line information (line 60) across multiple validators to identify which validators are processing which transactions, enabling targeted DoS or network partition attacks? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-logger/src/macros.rs] [Integration] [Async context loss] When logs are generated from async contexts spawned via spawn_named, is critical context like consensus round, epoch, or validator identity properly propagated, or can context loss cause logs to be misattributed and hide Byzantine behavior? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-logger/src/macros.rs] [Integration] [Log aggregation bypass] Can attackers exploit differences in how different validators format and emit logs via these macros to cause log aggregation systems to miss critical security events, allowing consensus attacks to go undetected? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-logger/src/macros.rs] [Integration] [Memory exhaustion] If log events are buffered before being written to disk, can attackers trigger rapid logging via these macros to exhaust validator memory, causing OOM crashes during critical consensus operations like epoch changes? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-logger/src/macros.rs] [Integration] [Event dispatch blocking] Does Event::dispatch() on line 64 block the calling thread, and if so, can attackers trigger expensive logging operations in hot consensus paths that introduce latency and cause validators to miss round deadlines? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-logger/src/macros.rs] [Integration] [Log rotation race] Can race conditions during log file rotation cause logs generated via these macros to be lost or corrupted, potentially hiding evidence of consensus attacks or Byzantine validator behavior during security investigations? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-logger/src/macros.rs] [Integration] [Panic propagation] If any of the referenced types (Metadata, Event, KeyValue, Value) panic during construction or dispatch, do these panics properly unwind through the macros, or can they cause validators to crash without proper error handling? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-logger/src/macros.rs] [Macro hygiene] [Name collision] Can the use of common internal names like $out, $args, $k, $val in macro patterns (e.g., lines 132-254) collide with user code variables, causing unexpected variable capture and leading to incorrect log output or state corruption?
